The support vector machine algorithm with a Gaussian kernel achieved the best result of 81.4% in cross-validation and 82.03% in independent validation for the latter database. The best performing model was used to build a cleaning function for automatic pre-processing and classification of spectra into soil or non-soil classes. This automatic spectrum filtering system saves time and ensures only high-quality spectra are used for accurate online prediction of soil properties. ###

This approach helps to eliminate the negative impact of surface features on cloud detection, ensuring more accurate identification and classification of clouds using mid-infrared remote sensing spectrum.

Purpose: The purpose of the study is to develop machine learning-based cloud detection algorithms using spectral observations for the Advanced Himawari Imager (AHI) onboard the Himawari-8 geostationary satellite. The algorithms are compared to the AHI operational algorithm and validated against observations from Cloud-Aerosol Lidar with Orthogonal Polarization (CALIOP). ###

P2. Methods: The study uses collocated active observations from CALIOP to provide reference labels for model development and validation. The researchers introduce both daytime and nighttime algorithms, with the daytime algorithm including solar band observations and the nighttime algorithm using only infrared observations. The artificial neural network (ANN) and random forest (RF) techniques are adopted for comparison. Three models with different treatments of the surface are developed to eliminate the influences of surface conditions on cloud detection. Surface variables are added in a binary way to enhance the accuracy of the ML-based algorithms. ###

P3. Conclusions: The daytime RF-based algorithm outperforms the AHI operational algorithm by improving the accuracy of cloudy pixel detection by approximately 5% and reducing misjudgment by approximately 3%. Overall, the ML-based algorithms developed in this study can serve as a reliable method to provide cloud mask results for both daytime and nighttime AHI observations. The researchers suggest treating the surface with a set of independent variables for future ML-based algorithm development. ###

model_response: The distributional method improves the classification of clear and cloudy scenes based on spectral detection when using mid-infrared remote sensing spectrum to identify and classify clouds by considering the distribution of spectral values within each class, rather than just the mean spectral values.
